meta.content: Ball mill assisted synthesis of cobalt–iron sulfide/N-doped carbon for high performance asymmetric supercapacitors
meta.name: twitter:title

meta.content: Journal of Applied Electrochemistry - Cobalt–iron sulfides supported on N-doped carbon were synthesized as energy storage material using ball milling followed by carbonization. As-synthesized...
meta.name: twitter:description

meta.content: Ball mill assisted synthesis of cobalt–iron sulfide/N-doped carbon for high performance asymmetric supercapacitors
meta.name: dc.title

meta.content: Journal of Applied Electrochemistry 2020 50:11
meta.name: dc.source

meta.content: 2020 Springer Nature B.V.
meta.name: dc.copyright

meta.content: Cobalt–iron sulfides supported on N-doped carbon were synthesized as energy storage material using ball milling followed by carbonization. As-synthesized materials were structurally analyzed by X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy. Furthermore, cobalt–iron sulfides supported on N-doped carbon were coated on Ni foam, and their electrochemical performance was tested in a 3-M KOH electrolyte. The as-fabricated Co–Fe–S-2 electrode registered a specific capacitance of 1252 F g−1 at 1 A g−1 and also showed capacitance retention of 66.4% at 20 A g−1. In addition, asymmetric supercapacitors (ASC) were fabricated using the as-synthesized electrode materials and it had a voltage window of 0–1.6 V. Among them, the activated carbon (AC)//Co–Fe–S-2 ASC device showed maximum specific capacitance of 169.3 F g−1 at 1 A g−1, and it registered maximum energy density of 59.6 Wh kg−1 at power density of 0.796 kW kg−1. The AC//Co–Fe–S-2 device delivered a rate capability of 55.6% at 30 A g−1, and it reveals a capacitance retention of 76.3% over 5000 cycles. Herein we also found that ball-milling-assisted synthesis of Co–Fe–S-2 electrode material is a promising candidate for high-performance ASCs.

meta.content: Ball mill assisted synthesis of cobalt–iron sulfide/N-doped carbon for high performance asymmetric supercapacitors - Journal of Applied Electrochemistry

Abstract Cobalt–iron sulfides supported on N-doped carbon were synthesized as energy storage material using ball milling followed by carbonization. As-synthesized materials were structurally analyzed by X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy. Furthermore, cobalt–iron sulfides supported on N-doped carbon were coated on Ni foam, and their electrochemical performance was tested in a 3-M KOH electrolyte. The as-fabricated Co–Fe–S-2 electrode registered a specific capacitance of 1252 F g−1 at 1 A g−1 and also showed capacitance retention of 66.4% at 20 A g−1. In addition, asymmetric supercapacitors (ASC) were fabricated using the as-synthesized electrode materials and it had a voltage window of 0–1.6 V. Among them, the activated carbon (AC)//Co–Fe–S-2 ASC device showed maximum specific capacitance of 169.3 F g−1 at 1 A g−1, and it registered maximum energy density of 59.6 Wh kg−1 at power density of 0.796 kW kg−1. The AC//Co–Fe–S-2 device delivered a rate capability of 55.6% at 30 A g−1, and it reveals a capacitance retention of 76.3% over 5000 cycles. Herein we also found that ball-milling-assisted synthesis of Co–Fe–S-2 electrode material is a promising candidate for high-performance ASCs. Graphic abstract

head.title: Ball mill assisted synthesis of cobalt–iron sulfide/N-doped carbon for high performance asymmetric supercapacitors | SpringerLink

div.div: Ball mill assisted synthesis of cobalt–iron sulfide/N-doped carbon for high performance asymmetric supercapacitors

header.h1: Ball mill assisted synthesis of cobalt–iron sulfide/N-doped carbon for high performance asymmetric supercapacitors
header.p:
Journal of Applied Electrochemistry
volume
50
,
pages
1119–1128 (
2020
)
Cite this article

li.p:
414
Accesses

5
Citations

div.p:
Cobalt–iron sulfides supported on N-doped carbon were synthesized as energy storage material using ball milling followed by carbonization. As-synthesized materials were structurally analyzed by X-ray diffraction, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy. Furthermore, cobalt–iron sulfides supported on N-doped carbon were coated on Ni foam, and their electrochemical performance was tested in a 3-M KOH electrolyte. The as-fabricated Co–Fe–S-2 electrode registered a specific capacitance of 1252 F g
−1
at 1 A g
−1
and also showed capacitance retention of 66.4% at 20 A g
−1
. In addition, asymmetric supercapacitors (ASC) were fabricated using the as-synthesized electrode materials and it had a voltage window of 0
–
1.6 V. Among them, the activated carbon (AC)//Co–Fe–S-2 ASC device showed maximum specific capacitance of 169.3 F g
−1
at 1 A g
−1
, and it registered maximum energy density of 59.6 Wh kg
−1
at power density of 0.796 kW kg
−1
. The AC//Co–Fe–S-2 device delivered a rate capability of 55.6% at 30 A g
−1
, and it reveals a capacitance retention of 76.3% over 5000 cycles. Herein we also found that ball-milling-assisted synthesis of Co–Fe–S-2 electrode material is a promising candidate for high-performance ASCs.

Supercapacitors were identified as promising energy storage devices due to their high power density, fast charge–discharge ability, long-term durability, light weight, and low environmental impact [
1
,
2
,
3
,
4
]. With respect to their storage mechanism, supercapacitors have been classified as electrical double-layer capacitors (EDLC) and pseudocapacitors (PC) [
5
,
6
]. EDLCs store charge between the electrode/electrolyte interface, and PCs save the energy through faradaic redox reactions. EDLCs based on carbon materials have less energy storage capability than PCs fabricated with transition metal hydroxides/oxides and conduction polymers [
7
,
8
,
9
]. Recently, transition metal sulfides, including CoS
2
[
10
], NiS [
11
], MoS [
12
], and CuS [
13
], have gained more attention due to their electrical conductivity and better electrochemical activity [
14
]. Among these metal sulfides, cobalt sulfide (Co
x
S
y
) has been identified as a promising pseudocapacitive electrode material.

Generally, the electrochemical performance of electrode materials is directly related to their morphology and their synthesis techniques. For instance, Bao et al. reported a hydrothermal-assisted synthesis method for cobalt sulfide nanowires, which exhibited a specific capacitance of 508 F g
−1
at a fixed current density of 2.5 mA cm
−2
[
15
]. Wan et al. concluded that hydrothermally synthesized CoS nanotubes exhibit a specific capacitance of 285 F g
−1
at 0.5 A g
−1
[
16
]. Jiang et al. reported the efficient synthesis of hollow CoS nanocages from a thioacetamide-based ZIF-67 template and demonstrated a specific capacitance of 1475 F g
−1
at 1 A g
−1
[
17
]. Han et al. synthesized CoS material from a ZIF-67 template and revealed a high specific capacitance of 1098 F g
−1
at 0.5 A g
−1
[
18
].

Furthermore, Ni/Cu/Mn/Fe transition metals doped with cobalt sulfides enhanced pseudocapacitive. Zhang et al. reported flower-like CuCo
2
S
4
electrode materials which show a specific capacitance of 908.9 F g
−1
at 5 mA cm
−2
[
19
]. Lee et al. synthesized manganese cobalt sulfide (MnCo
2
S
4
) nanoparticles via the hydrothermal method, and a specific capacitance of 1150 F g
−1
at a fixed current density of 1 A g
−1
was attained [
20
]. Haj et al. made N-rGO supported iron cobalt sulfide nanoparticles which had a specific capacitance of 1374 F g
−1
at a fixed current density of 2 A g
−1
[
21
]. Yang et al. synthesized nickel cobalt sulfide decorated on graphene frameworks via the hydrothermal method, and it registered a specific capacitance of 1492 F g
−1
at a fixed current density of 1 A g
−1
[
22
]. From recent studies, it was observed that many of the bimetallic sulfide electrode materials were synthesized through the hydrothermal method. When considering large-scale production, however, it is not a reasonable approach for making bimetallic sulfide materials.

In this study, cobalt–iron sulfides, supported on nitrogen-doped carbons, were synthesized by ball-milling the precursors of aniline, 2-fluoroaniline, thiourea, ammonium persulfate, Co(NO
3
)
2
·6H
2
O, and FeCl
3
·6H
2
O at 500 rpm and carbonizing them at 900 °C for 1 h. Structural characterization by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) helped elucidate the crystalline structure, carbon bonding, morphology, and surface element compositions, respectively. Additionally, the electrochemical performance of cobalt–iron sulfides (Co–Fe–S) was evaluated in both three-electrode and two-electrode systems. In a half-cell study, the Co–Fe–S-2 electrode registered a maximum specific capacitance of 1252 F g
−1
at 1 A g
−1
. Similarly, the assembled AC//Co–Fe–S-2 device showed a maximum device capacitance of 169.3 F g
−1
at 1 A g
−1
. Thus, the suggested method was validated as an efficient way of synthesizing bimetallic sulfide-supported N-doped carbon materials.

Cobalt–iron sulfides (Co–Fe–S) supported on N-doped carbon materials were prepared by following two steps. Initially, 0.51 mL of aniline, 1.1 mL of 2-fluoroaniline, 1.5 g of ammonium persulfate, 1.23 g of Co(NO
3
)
2
·6H
2
O, and 0.6 g of FeCl
3
·6H
2
O were transferred into an 80-mL stainless steel (SS) bowl which contained around 270 number SS beads with the diameter of 5 mm. Then, the SS bowl was sealed airtight and fixed in the FRITSCH planetary mono mill. The mixture was then ground at 500 rpm for 9 min. After the mechanochemical co-polymerization, 2 g of thiourea and 0.05 mL water were added to the SS bowl, and grinding continued for an additional 9 min. After the ball milling process, the powder form of Fe and Co ions bonded poly(An-F-An) co-polymers and thiourea mixture was collected and carbonized at 900 °C for 1 h with a heating rate of 3 °C min
−1
in an N
2
atmosphere. It was named Co–Fe–S-1. In addition, the quantities of the metal precursors were increased two- and threefold, and they were named Co–Fe–S-2 (2.47 g of Co(NO
3
)
2
·6H
2
O and 1.21 g of FeCl
3
·6H
2
O) and Co–Fe–S-3 (3.7 g of Co(NO
3
)
2
·6H
2
O and 1.81 g of FeCl
3
·6H
2
O), respectively. Ball mill assisted synthesis method can achieved the electrode materials minimum quantity of 1.5 g at single batch.

The crystalline nature of Co–Fe–S materials was analyzed using X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) technique on a Smart Lab X-ray diffraction analyzer (Rigaku). The morphological studies were evaluated by using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (JSM-7800F, JEOL) and HR-TEM (Talos F200X, FEI instruments). High-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) helped evaluate the elemental mapping results. Raman spectra were obtained using a wavelength of 633 nm (LabRAM HR800). X-ray photo electron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed to investigate the oxidation state of elements (PHI 5000 VersaProbe II, ULVAC-PHI). The electrochemical performances of the as-synthesized materials were evaluated using cyclic voltammetry (CV), and galvanic charge/discharge (GCD) in three- and two-electrode systems with a 3-M KOH electrolyte (AUTOLAB M204). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed for as prepared electrodes from 10 kHz to 0.01 Hz frequency with respect to open circuit potential. The working electrode was prepared by mixing the Co–Fe–S, vulcan XC-72 carbon and polyvinylidine fluoride (PVDF) with a weight ratio of 17:2:1, making a paste with 0.2 mL of
N
-methyl pyrrolidone, and coating it on 1 cm
2
Ni foam. The Ni foam coated with active material was dried at 80 °C for 6 h. The areal mass loading of active material is maintained in all electrodes around 6 mg cm
−2
. Leak-free Ag/AgCl (eDAQ, ETO72) used as reference electrode and Pt coil is used as counter electrode. Asymmetric supercapacitors (ASC) device was assembled using Co–Fe–S active materials and tested in 3 m KOH. Ni foam coated with activated carbon (AC) was used as the anode, Ni foam coated with Co–Fe–S active material was introduced as the cathode, and glass fiber filter paper (ADVANTEC) was adopted as a separator. AC electrode was prepared by mixing 70 wt% of activated carbon, 20 wt% of PVDF binder, and 10 wt% of Vulcan X 72 carbon with NMP solvent and coating the mixture on Ni foam.

Here, I is discharging current (A) and Δt is discharging time (s). ‘m’ is total mass loading of active material on both anode and cathode and ΔV is actual potential window. The mass ratio between positive and negative electrodes were calculated using charge balance equation (q
+
= q
−
), which is described below.

The morphology of Co–Fe–S materials was analyzed using SEM. Figure
1
a, b show SEM images of Co–Fe–S-2 in low and high magnification, respectively. Nitrogen-doped carbon was not clearly seen in the SEM images because cobalt–iron sulfide fully covered the surface. SEM elemental mapping images (Figs. S1, S2, and S3) confirmed that the nitrogen-doped carbon was hidden within the Fe–Co–S crystals. As the amount of metal precursor increased from Co–Fe–S-1 to Co–Fe–S-3, the color of carbon become paler in the mapping images, while the hues of Co and Fe become darker. Low- and high-magnification HR-TEM images of Co–Fe–S-2 are displayed in Fig.
1
c, d, and HAADF-STEM elemental mapping analyses of Fig.
1
c are displayed in Fig.
2
a–f. The location of Co, Fe and S are overlap each other, thus it can be inferred that Co–Fe–S is successfully formed. In case of N, it is uniformly distributed throughout carbon and Co–Fe–S, even though the intensity is little different. From the nitrogen existing on carbon, the doping of N on carbon was indirectly proved.

a
,
b
SEM and
c
,
d
HR-TEM images at low and high magnification scale

HAADF-STEM elemental mapping images of
a
HAADF,
b
carbon,
c
nitrogen,
d
cobalt,
e
iron and
f
sulfur, respectively

The crystalline structures of Co–Fe–S materials were investigated using XRD analysis (Fig.
3
a). XRD patterns exhibite diffraction peaks at 15.3°, 29.8°, 31.2°, 39.5°, 47.6°, 51.9°, and 73.2°, corresponding to (111), (311), (222), (331), (511), (440), and (731) planes of Co
8
FeS
8
phase crystals (JCPDS no. 29-0484). XRD peaks at 30.5°, 35.0°, 46.3°, and 54.3° are attributed to (100), (101), (102), and (110) planes, respectively, of CoFeS
2
crystals (JCPDS no. 75-0607). XRD analysis confirms that two major phases of Co
8
FeS
8
and CoFeS
2
crystals exist in the as-synthesized materials. In addition to Co
8
FeS
8
and CoFeS
2
, Co–Fe–S-1 and Co–Fe–S-2 show the extra minor peaks at 33.7°, 43.7°, and 53.1° originating from (201), (202), and (220) planes of Co
0.2
Fe
0.8
S crystals (JCPDS no. 79-0596). Raman spectra in Fig.
3
b show two major peaks at 1343 and 1554 cm
−1
, which correspond to the D and G bands, respectively, which arise due to sp
2
carbon defects and vibrations of in-plane sp
2
carbon, respectively. In addition, a broad band appearing around 2800 cm
−1
is identified as the 2D band, which is caused by the highly ordered graphitic structure of carbon materials. There are a few minor peaks between 400 and 750 cm
−1
, which arise from Co–S stretching and vibrations in Co
x
S
y
crystals [
24
]. Raman spectral analysis confirms the presence of sp
2
carbon network along with Co
x
S
y
crystals in as-synthesized materials.

a
XRD pattern and
b
Raman spectrum of Co–Fe–S materials

The XPS spectrum of Co–Fe–S-2 (Fig.
4
a) indicates the presence of carbon (C 1s), nitrogen (N 1s), cobalt (Co 2p), iron (Fe 2p), and sulfur (S 2p), with compositions of 57.36%, 7.07%, 10.93%, 7.98%, and 16.66% of atomic percentage, respectively. The deconvoluted core-level spectrum of the Co 2p orbital is displayed in Fig.
4
b. In the Co 2p spectrum, the Co 2p
3/2
orbital shows +3 and +2 ionic state peaks at 778.4 eV and 782.0 eV, and the Co 2p
1/2
orbital reveals +3 and +2 ionic state peaks at 797.6 eV and 799.4 eV, respectively. In Fig.
4
c, the Fe 2p
3/2
orbitals display +2 and +3 oxidation state peaks appearing at 711.0 eV and 713.7 eV, and the Fe 2p
1/2
orbitals include +2 and +3 oxidation state peaks at 723.8.0 and 725.7 eV. The XPS spectrum of the S 2p orbital was deconvoluted into S 2p
3/2
(161.7 eV), S 2p
3/2
(163.5 eV), and oxidized sulfur (168.9 eV) peaks as shown in Fig.
4
d. In addition, the N 1s spectrum was deconvoluted into four peaks which correspond to pyridinic-N (398.1 eV), pyrrolic-N (399.1 eV), graphitic-N (400.6 eV), and pyridinic N-oxide (401.3 eV). The C 1s and N 1s spectra are displayed in Fig. S4. XPS spectra reveal that cobalt and iron metals exist in multiple oxidation states which may be helpful for boosting the energy storage performance in Co–Fe–S materials [
21
].

a
XPS survey spectrum of Co–Fe–S-2 and deconvoluted XPS spectrum of
b
Co 2p,
c
Fe 2p and
d
S 2p orbitals in Co–Fe–S-2

The electrochemical performance of Co–Fe–S electrodes was evaluated by CV and GCD techniques in a three-electrode system using 3 m KOH electrolytic solution. Figure
5
a reveals the CV curves of Co–Fe–S electrodes are polarized between 0 and 0.45 V vs. Ag/AgCl at a scan rate of 50 mV s
−1
. All CV curves show a pair of redox peaks which occur due to the faradaic redox reaction between the electro-active materials (Fe
2+
/ Fe
3+
and Co
2+
/Co
3+
) and OH
−
ions [
25
]. The area obtained by integrating CV curves shown in Fig.
5
a reveals that Co–Fe–S-2 has greater pseudocapacitance properties than other electrodes. Furthermore, GCD curves of Co–Fe–S electrodes (Fig.
5
b) were obtained at a fixed current density of 1 A g
−1
in 3 m KOH electrolytic solution. The GCD curves show that the Co–Fe–S-2 electrode experiences a longer discharging time than the other two electrodes at an identical current density. This means that the Co–Fe–S-2 electrode has significantly higher specific capacitance than the other two electrodes. The calculated specific capacitances of the Co–Fe–S-1, Co–Fe–S-2, and Co–Fe–S-3 electrodes were 758 F g
−1
, 1252 F g
−1
and 1065.0 F g
−1
, respectively. The specific capacitance of the Co–Fe–S-2 is higher than or similar with the specific capacitances reported in previous studies (Table S1). Figure
5
c shows the CV curves of the Co–Fe–S-2 electrode polarized with various scan rates from 10 to 100 mV s
−1
. The CV curves retained similar shapes throughout the experiments even at high scan rates which indicates good rate capacity and reversibility. For specific surface area, CV was also performed in non-Faradaic region at different scan rates of 10, 20, 30, 50, 70, 100 mV s
−1
as shown in Fig. S5. The calculated specific surface areas of Co–Fe–S-1, Co–Fe–S-2 and Co–Fe–S-3 electrodes were 11.4, 14.1 and 12.9 m
2
g
−1
, respectively.

a
CV curves of Co–Fe–S electrodes at scan rate of 50 mV s
−1
,
b
GCD curves of Co–Fe–S electrodes at fixed current density of 1 A g
−1
,
c
CV curves of Co–Fe–S-2 electrode at various scan rate from 10 to 100 mV s
−1
,
d
GCD curves of Co–Fe–S-2 electrode at various current densities (1–20 A g
−1
),
e
specific capacitance vs. current density of Co–Fe–S electrodes,
f
EIS spectrum of Co–Fe–S electrodes

GCD curves of the Co–Fe–S-2 electrode (Fig.
5
d) were evaluated at various current densities ranging from 1 to 20 A g
−1
. According to the curve analysis, discharging time decreased steadily with respect to the current density increase. Figure
5
e deals with the specific capacitance of Co–Fe–S electrodes at various current densities between 1 and 20 A g
−1
. The specific capacitance of Co–Fe–S-1, Co–Fe–S-2, and Co–Fe–S-3 electrodes was evaluated as 566 F g
−1
, 831 F g
−1
, and 702 F g
−1
at 20 A g
−1
, respectively. Even at a 20 A g
−1
current density, Co–Fe–S-1, Co–Fe–S-2, and Co–Fe–S-3 electrodes retained rate capacities of 74.7%, 66.4%, and 65.9% compared to their initial specific capacitance. Co–Fe–S-1 electrodes demonstrated slightly higher capacity retention compared to other electrodes due to their higher carbon content which enables better electronic transport through the electrodes at high current density [
26
]. CV and GCD curves of Co–Fe–S-1 and Co–Fe–S-3 electrodes are displayed in Fig. S6. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy was performed to investigate the charge transfer kinetics of Co–Fe–S electrodes. EIS spectra (Fig.
5
f) shows a semi-circle shape in the high-frequency region and a straight line in the low frequency region, corresponding to the charge transfer resistance (R
ct
) and Warburg resistance, respectively. The inset image in Fig.
5
f shows that Co–Fe–S-1, Co–Fe–S-2, and Co–Fe–S-3 electrodes exhibit R
Ω
values of 0.35 Ω, 0.43 Ω and 0.40 Ω respectively. Within the low-frequency region, the Co–Fe–S-2 electrode exhibits a higher slope (5.76) than Co–Fe–S-1 (3.77) and Co–Fe–S-3 (3.14) electrodes, which explains the superior capacitance of the Co–Fe–S-2 electrode.

To investigate real applications of the ASCs, aqueous ASCs were assembled using a Co–Fe–S cathode, an activated carbon anode, and a glass fiber filter paper separator. The assembled ASC devices were electrochemically polarized between 0 and 1.6 V at a scan rate of 50 mV s
−1
using 3 m KOH electrolytic solution, and the results are shown in Fig.
6
a. Notably, all the CV curves have broad redox peaks due to the pseudocapacitive nature of the electrodes. Their integral areas indicate that Co–Fe–S-2//AC devices register higher capacitance than other ASC devices. Figure
6
b displays GCD curves of Co–Fe–S//AC ASC devices performed at a current density of 1 A g
−1
. From GCD curves, the specific capacitances were estimated as 116.2 F g
−1
, 169.3 F g
−1
, and 143.2 F g
−1
for Co–Fe–S-1//AC, Co–Fe–S-2//AC, and Co–Fe–S-3//AC ASC devices, respectively. CV and GCD results also revealed that Co–Fe–S-2//AC devices have superior capacitance characteristics compared to Co–Fe–S//AC ASC devices. CV curves were obtained using Co–Fe–S-2//AC devices at various scan rates from 10 to 100 mV s
−1
, and Fig.
6
c shows the results. CV curves demonstrate high rate capacity retentions even at higher scan rates.

a
CV curves of Co–Fe–S//AC devices obtained at the scan rate of 50 mV s
−1
,
b
GCD curves of Co–Fe–S//AC devices obtained at the fixed current density of 1 A g
−1
,
c
CV curves of Co–Fe–S-2//AC device measured at various scan rate from 10 to 100 mV s
−1
,
d
GCD curves of AC//Co–Fe–S-2 device electrode obtained by varying current densities (1–30 A g
−1
),
e
specific capacitance vs. current density of Co–Fe–S//AC devices,
f
Durability over 5000 cycles of Co–Fe–S-2//AC device (inset; photograph of blue LED lighting by two serially connected Co–Fe–S-2//AC device)

Similarly, GCD curves were extracted for Co–Fe–S-2//AC devices by varying current density from 1 to 30 A g
−1
. The shape and pattern of GCD curves (Fig.
6
d) at high current density indicate good electrochemical reversibility. Figure
6
e displays the plot of specific capacitance against current densities of Co–Fe–S//AC ASC devices. GCD results show that Co–Fe–S-2//AC devices register enhanced performances of 169.3 F g
−1
, 148.7 F g
−1
, 137.5 F g
−1
, 125.0 F g
−1
, 108.7 F g
−1
, 100.1 F g
−1
, and 94.3 F g
−1
at current densities of 1, 3, 5, 10, 20, and 30 A g
−1
. Co–Fe–S-1//AC, Co–Fe–S-2//AC, and Co–Fe–S-3//AC devices registered capacitance retentions of 40.5%, 55.6%, and 52.7% at 30 A g
− 1
, respectively. ASC device shows lower capacitance retentions than that of a three-electrode system due to a higher current density of 30 A g
−1
causing larger ohmic drop and sluggish kinetic. In addition, separator and contact resistance between the electrode and electrolyte interface may play roles to reduce the capacitance retention in ASC device. CV and GCD curves of Co–Fe–S-1//AC and Co–Fe–S-3//AC devices are displayed in Fig. S7. Ragone plot (energy density vs. power density) for Co–Fe–S//AC devices were displayed in Fig. S7(e). As fabricated Co–Fe–S-1//AC, Co–Fe–S-2//AC and Co–Fe–S-3//AC ASC devices registered higher energy density of 40.8, 59.6, and 50.4 Wh kg
−1
at power density of 0.795, 0.796, and 0.795 kW kg
−1
, respectively. Similarly, Co–Fe–S-1//AC, Co–Fe–S-2//AC and Co–Fe–S-3//AC ASC devices registered the lower energy density of 12.8, 26.8, and 21.4 Wh kg
−1
at higher power density of 21.0, 21.4, 21.4 kW kg
−1
, respectively. Ragone plot clearly indicates that Co–Fe–S-2//AC device delivered higher energy density than other two ASC devices as well as recently reported devices [
27
,
28
,
29
,
30
]. To investigate the cycling stability of Co–Fe–S-2, Co–Fe–S-2//AC ASC devices were subjected to long-term cycling stability testing over 5000 cycles between 0 and 1.6 V at 10 A g
−1
, and the results are displayed in Fig.
6
f. The Co–Fe–S-2//AC device demonstrated capacitance retention of 76.3 F g
−1
over 5000 cycles. Finally, a pair of Co–Fe–S-2//AC solid state ASC devices was fabricated using PVA/KOH gel, and they were connected in series to light up a blue LED for more than 5 min. The LED lighting image is inserted in Fig.
6
f. Co–Fe–S-2 electrocatalyst is an efficient energy storage material which can be synthesized on a large-scale using ball milling and its enhanced performance in supercapacitors makes the material commercially viable in energy storage industries.

In summary, an efficient energy storage material composed of cobalt–iron–sulfide supported on N-doped carbon was synthesized using ball milling, followed by carbonization. Among the synthesized materials, Co–Fe–S-2 exhibited a maximum specific capacitance of 1252 F g
−1
at 1 A g
−1
, and capacitance retention of 66.4% at a current density of 20 A g
−1
. Furthermore, assembled AC//Co–Fe–S-2 ASC devices registered superior device capacitance and showed a maximum specific capacitance of 169.3 F g
−1
at 1 A g
−1
. AC//Co–Fe–S-2 devices delivered a rate capability of 55.6% at 30 A g
−1
and exhibited better cycling stability over 5000 cycles at 10 A g
−1
. Due to the low cost and large quantity of product obtained via ball milling synthesis, Co–Fe–S-2 electrocatalyst could be a promising energy storage material.
